title: Getting started with Go concurrency
body: Today I experimented with goroutines and channels. The simplicity is deceptive but powerful.

title: Why slices feel like pointers
body: Coming from C++, Go slices feel familiar. Header copies, shared backing arrays, subtle bugs.

title: Designing an in-memory repository
body: I prototyped an in-memory repo for rapid iteration. Returning slices needs discipline.

title: Email HTML is harder than it looks
body: Modern CSS habits break fast in email clients. Tables still rule everything.

title: Background images in Gmail
body: Gmail mobile ignores half of CSS. The only reliable way is table-based layout.

title: Understanding heap escape in Go
body: Escape analysis decides allocation, not pointers. Compiler behavior matters.

title: Returning slices from repositories
body: Returning slices exposes internal memory. Sometimes fine, sometimes dangerous.

title: When to return pointers in Go
body: Use pointers for mutation, large structs, or identity. Not by default.

title: Go feels like modern C
body: Explicit, predictable, minimal magic. A good fit for backend systems.

title: Why net/http still scales
body: Despite being simple, net/http handles massive traffic when used correctly.

title: Building a custom router abstraction
body: Abstracting routing allows swapping frameworks without touching business logic.

title: Why gin handlers need adapters
body: Standard http handlers make portability easier across frameworks.

title: Go-zero service context explained
body: The service context wires configs, DBs, caches, and clients together.

title: Why shallow copies are dangerous
body: Shared backing arrays can mutate state across layers silently.

title: Copy-on-read vs copy-on-write
body: Choosing the right strategy depends on ownership and mutation rules.

title: Mocking repositories cleanly
body: Interfaces plus in-memory slices give fast, reliable tests.

title: Why immutability helps
body: Immutability reduces mental load, especially across service boundaries.

title: Layered architecture in Go
body: Repo → Service → Handler keeps responsibilities clean.

title: Avoid premature optimization
body: Measure first. Most performance bugs are imaginary.

title: Readable code scales better
body: Clear intent beats clever tricks every time.

title: Understanding handler ownership
body: Handlers should orchestrate, not own business logic. Keep them thin.

title: Why returning DTOs matters
body: Returning domain models leaks internals. DTOs create safer boundaries.

title: Designing APIs for change
body: Assume every API will evolve. Versioning and contracts are key.

title: Go interfaces are implicit
body: Implicit interfaces reduce coupling and make refactoring easier.

title: When NOT to use pointers
body: Small immutable structs work best as values. Don’t overuse pointers.

title: Understanding Go memory model
body: Knowing when data is shared prevents subtle race conditions.

title: Concurrency is not parallelism
body: Concurrency is structure. Parallelism is execution.

title: Email clients are hostile environments
body: Every client breaks something different. Expect inconsistency.

title: Why tables still dominate email HTML
body: Flexbox and grid are unreliable. Tables are predictable.

title: Testing handlers without servers
body: httptest makes handler testing fast and isolated.

title: Why dependency injection matters
body: Explicit dependencies make systems easier to test and evolve.

title: Avoid shared mutable state
body: Shared state is the root of most concurrency bugs.

title: Go encourages composition
body: Composition over inheritance leads to simpler designs.

title: Understanding zero values
body: Zero values make Go APIs safer and easier to use.

title: Why context.Context matters
body: Context propagates cancellation, deadlines, and request scope.

title: Designing cancelable workflows
body: Cancellation should be part of the design, not an afterthought.

title: Why logging is not observability
body: Logs help debugging, metrics help understanding systems.

title: Handling errors explicitly
body: Explicit error handling improves reliability and clarity.

title: Avoid panics in production code
body: Panics are for programmer errors, not runtime conditions.

title: Designing clean service layers
body: Service layers should express business intent clearly.

title: Immutability simplifies reasoning
body: Immutable data reduces hidden side effects.

title: Go favors explicitness
body: What you see is what you pay for — no hidden magic.

title: Why code reviews matter
body: Reviews catch bugs, spread knowledge, and improve design.

title: Write code for humans
body: The compiler is forgiving. Humans are not.

title: Consistency beats cleverness
body: Consistent patterns reduce cognitive load.

title: Avoid leaking internal slices
body: Returning internal slices allows accidental mutation.

title: Defensive copying strategies
body: Copy-on-read can prevent entire classes of bugs.

title: Why ownership rules matter
body: Clear ownership prevents unintended side effects.

title: Go encourages simple APIs
body: Small APIs are easier to understand and maintain.

title: Clarity over abstraction
body: Abstract only when repetition forces you to.

title: Avoid framework lock-in
body: Keep business logic independent of frameworks.

title: Write tests you trust
body: Flaky tests destroy confidence in codebases.

title: Prefer simple data structures
body: Simple structures are easier to reason about.

title: Understand your tools deeply
body: Depth beats breadth when building reliable systems.

title: Trade-offs are unavoidable
body: Every design decision carries a cost.

title: Why simplicity scales
body: Simple systems fail less and recover faster.

title: Engineering is decision making
body: Code reflects the decisions you made under constraints.

title: Good APIs age well
body: Stable APIs reduce churn and friction.

title: Refactoring is continuous
body: Refactoring keeps systems healthy over time.

title: Optimize for readability
body: Readable code outlives clever optimizations.

title: APIs are contracts
body: Breaking contracts breaks trust with users.

title: Code reflects thought quality
body: Messy code often signals unclear thinking.

title: Design for failure
body: Failures are inevitable. Design for graceful recovery.

title: Observability is a feature
body: Systems without visibility are impossible to operate.

title: Clean code reduces bugs
body: Clarity removes entire classes of errors.

title: Minimize global state
body: Global state hides dependencies and creates coupling.

title: APIs should be boring
body: Boring APIs are predictable and reliable.

title: Focus on correctness first
body: Fast wrong answers are still wrong.

title: Concurrency needs discipline
body: Concurrency magnifies both good and bad design.

title: Good names matter
body: Names communicate intent better than comments.

title: Short functions scale better
body: Small functions are easier to test and reason about.

title: Avoid hidden side effects
body: Side effects should be obvious and explicit.

title: Document design decisions
body: Future maintainers will thank you.

title: Consistency enables velocity
body: Teams move faster when patterns are predictable.

title: Code is read more than written
body: Optimize for readers, not writers.

title: Build small, compose later
body: Small pieces compose better than monoliths.

title: Design APIs you’d enjoy using
body: Empathy improves API quality.

title: Avoid unnecessary abstractions
body: Abstractions have a cost. Earn them.

title: Code review is knowledge sharing
body: Reviews spread context across the team.

title: Avoid magic behavior
body: Explicit behavior is easier to debug.

title: Write boring production code
body: Production code should be predictable, not clever.

title: Understand before optimizing
body: Optimizing without understanding creates bugs.

title: Clear boundaries reduce bugs
body: Boundaries enforce discipline.

title: Prefer explicit data flow
body: Hidden data flow creates confusion.

title: Make invalid states impossible
body: Types are your first line of defense.

title: Errors are part of the API
body: Error handling defines API quality.

title: Prefer explicit lifetimes
body: Lifetimes should be obvious in code.

title: Design for readability first
body: Readable code accelerates teams.

title: Be conservative with mutability
body: Mutation should be intentional and rare.

title: Code is a communication tool
body: You’re writing for future readers.

title: Stable interfaces enable growth
body: Stability enables teams to move independently.

title: Minimize cognitive overhead
body: Less thinking means fewer mistakes.

title: Design APIs defensively
body: Assume misuse and guard against it.

title: Simple systems are resilient
body: Complex systems fail in complex ways.

title: Consistency beats documentation
body: Consistent patterns reduce the need for docs.

title: Prefer boring architectures
body: Boring architectures are proven and stable.

title: Design for maintainability
body: Maintenance cost dominates system lifetime.

title: Clear code enables speed
body: Teams move faster with clarity.

title: Explicit contracts reduce bugs
body: Contracts make assumptions visible.

title: Software is about trade-offs
body: There are no perfect solutions, only balanced ones.
